choices.text: Point B to C: Na+ channel opening

questions.text: Action potential is recorded from a mammalian neuron and marked with different letter. Which of the following pair is correct?
questions.solution:
A-Resting membrane potential: membrane is more permeable to K + than Na + at rest. Voltage-gated Na + and K + channels are closed.

B- Membrane depolarization: Na + activation gate opens -> Na + flows inward.

D- Membrane repolarization: Na + inactivation gate closes at peak potential, thus stopping Na+ inflow. K + activation gate opens -> K + flows outward.

E- Membrane hyperpolarization: K + activation gates are slow to close -> excess K + efflux and brief period of hyperpolarization. Voltage-gated Na + channels switch back to resting state. Na+ /K+ pump restores ions concentration

choices.text: A fibres are more susceptible to pressure to C fibres
B fibres are more susceptible to pressure to A fibres
C fibres are more susceptible to hypoxia to A fibres
C fibres are more susceptible to pressure to A fibres

questions.solution: Based on Erlanger and gasser classification:

questions.text: Tetany will result from which of the following disorder?
questions.solution:
TETANY is seen in:

  • Alkalosis
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia

During hyperventilation CO2 will be washed out. Greater amount of the calcium will bind with plasma proteins (albumin). Therefore patients with respiratory alkalosis are more susceptible for hypocalamic tetany.

While in acidosis, less calcium bind with plasma proteins so more free calcium

questions.text: Water hammer pulse is seen in-
questions.solution:
Watson's water hammer pulse, also known as Corrigan's pulse or collapsing pulse, is the medical sign (seen in aortic regurgitation) which describes a pulse that is bounding and forceful, rapidly increasing and subsequently collapsing, as if it were the sound of a water hammer that was causing the pulse.


Option c) aortic stenosis: shows pulsus parvus etardus

Option d) left ventricular failure: shows pulsus alternans

questions.text: Phase zero is the adjoining image is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Occurs in the SA and AV nodes. Key differences from the ventricular action potential include:

Phase 0 = upstroke-opening of voltage-gated Ca 2+ channels. Fast voltage-gated Na + channels are permanently inactivated because of the less negative resting potential of these cells. Results in a slow conduction velocity that is used by the AV node to prolong transmission from the atria to ventricles. Phases 1 and 2 are absent.

Phase 3 = repolarization-inactivation of the Ca 2+ channels andt↑activation of K + channels ->t↑ K+ efflux.

Phase 4 = slow spontaneous diastolic depolarization due to If ("funny current"). I f channels responsible for a slow, mixed Na + inward/K + outward current; different from I Na in phase 0 of ventricular action potential.

Accounts for automaticity of SA and AV nodes. The slope of phase 4 in the SA node determines HR. ACh/adenosinet↓ the rate of diastolic depolarization andt↓HR, while catecholaminest↑depolarization andt↑ HR. Sympathetic stimulation increases the chance that If channels are open and thust↑HR.

questions.text: TENS is used to relieve pain. What is the mechanism behind it?
questions.solution:
• Gate control theory is the mechanism behind Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS).
  • This method uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibers in the vicinity of the injury.
  • The relief is due to activation of innocuous cutaneous mechanoreceptors whose afferents emit collaterals that terminate in the dorsal horn.
  • The activity of these cutaneous mechanosensitive afferents reduce the responsiveness of dorsal horn neurons to their input from nociceptive afferent terminals.
  • This is called the gate-control mechanism of pain modulation.

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient visited the physician due to weakness and early fatigue. On evaluation it is found that he had high levels of blood urea, creatinine and increased PCO2 also. Which homeostatic function system among the following is found to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Above patient has accumulation of blood urea and creatinine and high PCO2 level. These waste products are excreted by the kidney (urea & creatinine) and respiratory system ( CO2).
  • Disturbance in kidney function leads to accumulation of urea and creatinine in the blood leading to early fatigue.
  • Skin helps in excretion of water and salts.
  • Liver also helps in excretion of waste products via bile (bilirubin and some drugs )
  • Here in this patient only urea and creatinine are increased in the blood so Dthe answer is a.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of integral protein?
questions.solution:
• There are two types of cell membrane proteins, integral proteins which protrude all the way through the membrane and peripheral proteins, which are attached only to one surface of the membrane and do not penetrate all the way through.
  • Enzymatic types of proteins are often attached to integral proteins and are examples of peripheral proteins.

  • Water channels, carrier proteins, and peptide receptors traverse on both sides of the membrane are examples of integral proteins.

Key Takeaway: Water channels, carrier proteins, and peptide receptors traverse on both sides of the membrane are examples of integral proteins.

choices.text: Regeneration is more rapid when there is cut injury and crushing injury
Presence of neurilemma slowers down the regeneration process
If the distance between two cut ends less than 3 mm and in the same line regeneration is faster

questions.text: Following is true about Wallerian degeneration and regeneration.
questions.solution:
• Wallerian degeneration and regeneration occurs following a nerve injury.
  • Regeneration takes place outside the CNS only where neurolemma is present and occurs in 20-0 days after injury
  • Regeneration is more rapid when there is crush injury than cut injury
  • Presence of neurilemma speeds up the regeneration
  • The distance between two cut ends is less than 3 mm and in the same line regeneration is faster.

Key Takeaway: Wallerian degeneration and regeneration.

choices.text: Compression of the sixth cranial nerve

questions.text: Reena, a 42 year old female, is presented to the emergency ward with severe headache and altered consciousness. A CT scan reveals large mass in the temporal lobe producing uncal herniation. Which of the following features may be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
• The uncus of the temporal lobe over the edge of the cerebellar tentorium occurs due to space occupying lesions from large tumors, hemorrhage, stroke, abscess.
  • It compresses the 3rd cranial nerve.
  • Also the patients are decerebrate and comatose, have fixed and dilated pupils, and eye movements are absent.
  • Involvement of midbrain leads to Cheyne-Stokes respiratory pattern develops, characterized by a pattern of waxing-and-waning depth of respiration followed by apnoea.
  • Later on breathing ceases and recovery is difficult.

Key Takeaway: Involvement of midbrain leads to Cheyne-Stokes respiratory pattern develops, characterized by a pattern of waxing-and-waning depth of respiration followed by apnoea.

questions.text: Following is a diagram of pacemaker potential. Identify the cause of potential change marked with an arrow.
questions.solution:
• Pacemaker potential is generated by pacemaker (SA node, AV node)
  • There are two types of voltage gated Ca++ channels in the heart.
  • L channels are longer lasting and T channels have transient activity.
  • The Ca2+ current (ICa) due to opening of T channels completes the prepotential, and Ica due to opening of L channels produces the impulse.
  • Repolarization from the peak of the impulse is due to Potassium conductance. Then it declines.
  • After Na+ and K+ channels open up following hyperpolarization, it refers to the h channel. The current through this channel is h current. They are also called funny (f) channels. As Ih increases, the membrane begins to depolarize forming the 1st part of the prepotential.

Key Takeaway:

After Na+ and K+ channels open up following hyperpolarization, it refers to the h channel. The current through this channel is h current. They are also called funny (f) channels.

questions.text: The cerebellum receives input from various areas of the body to keep the cerebellum aware about body positions. Which fibers do carry the proprioceptive input to the cerebellum?
questions.solution:
• The table shows primary afferents that converge to form climbing fibers or mossy fibers.
  • The input via olivocerebellar fibers form climbing fibers.
  • All other inputs form mossy fibers.

Key Takeaway: Cuneocerebellar fibers receives input from various areas of the body to keep the cerebellum aware about body positions.

questions.text: Which receptor contributes to static 2 point discrimination?
questions.solution:
Static two-point discrimination is the ability to distinguish two distinct points of contact on the skin when touched simultaneously. This ability depends on spatial resolution and receptor density, particularly in areas like the fingertips and lips.

Choice A: Merkel cells are specialized mechanoreceptors responsible for static touch, pressure sensing, and fine spatial resolution.

  • High receptor density in the fingertips allows precise discrimination between two closely spaced points.
  • Merkel cells provide high spatial resolution due to their slow-adapting (SA1) properties.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice B: Meissner corpuscles detect light touch and dynamic (moving) stimuli but have poor spatial resolution compared to Merkel cells. They are fast adapting receptors.

  • Fast-adapting (FA1) properties make them better for detecting motion (e.g., texture perception) rather than static touch.

Choice C: Pacinian corpuscles detect deep pressure and high-frequency vibrations.

  • Insensitive to fine spatial resolution, making them poor at two-point discrimination.

Choice D : As the option A is true not B and C. This is not correct choice.

Key Takeaway:

Merkel cells are responsible for static two-point discrimination due to their high spatial resolution and slow-adapting properties. Other receptors like Meissner corpuscles and Pacinian corpuscles are more suited for detecting dynamic stimuli or deep pressure, not fine spatial touch.

questions.text: Observe the following diagram of the normal pressure-volume loop of the left ventricle. Identify the phase of cardiac cycle from point c to point d.
questions.solution:
• In the above diagram to identify the phases we need to observe the pressure and volume changes.
  • From point c to d the pressure falls suddenly from approx. 120 mmHg to nearly 0 mmHg. But the volume remains nearly 50 ml through the whole phase.
  • If the volume is the same, the ventricle acts as a closed cavity when the AV valve and semilunar valves both are closed. It is meant to be an isometric phase. The pressure suddenly falls to nearly 0 suggests it is a relaxation phase. So from point c to d is isometric relaxation phase.
  • During diastolic phase ventricles are filled with blood with minimal pressure changes seen as from point d to a.
  • From point a to b pressure rises without change in volume shows the isometric contraction phase.
  • From point b to c the volume falls from around 130 ml to again 50 ml shows the emptying phase of the ventricle.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is undergoing a fitness test. For respiratory fitness he is advised ordinary spirometry. Which of the below list of volume/capacity can be measured by it?
questions.solution:
• Total lung capacity- It is the volume of air present in the lungs after maximal inspiration (Sum of inspiratory and expiratory reserve volumes plus the tidal volume and residual volume). It is nearly 5800 ml
  • Vital capacity -The maximum amount of air a person can expel from lungs after deepest possible inspiration. (Sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume) Its value is around 4600 ml
  • Functional residual capacity (FRC) - Amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration. (Expiratory reserve volume plus the residual volume). It is approx. 2300 ml.
  • Residual volume (RV) - Volume of air remaining in respiratory passages and lungs after the most forceful expiration (1200 ml).
  • Ordinary spirometry can not measure the residual volume in the lungs. FRC and total lung capacity includes residual volume. So, it is not possible to measure RV, FRC, TLC with spirometry.
  • Helium dilution or nitrogen washout method is used for RV measurement.

Key Takeaway:

  • Ordinary spirometry can not measure the residual volume in the lungs. FRC and total lung capacity includes residual volume. So, it is not possible to measure RV, FRC, TLC with spirometry.
  • Helium dilution or nitrogen washout method is used for RV measurement.

choices.text: Resting cardiac output increases due to training
Maximal Cardiac output can be increased during exercise due to training
Resting heart rate becomes less than 60/min

questions.text: Among the list of the following which are not the benefits of regular exercise training.
questions.solution:
• Due to regular training in exercise there is an increase in heart activity of the heart leading to hypertrophy of cardiac muscles. It causes enlargement of chambers.
  • There is no change in resting cardiac output.
  • Cardiac output=Stroke volume * heart rate
  • Due to training heart rate is reduced below 60/min. But stroke volume is increased due to hypertrophy of cardiac muscles. No change in resting cardiac output occurs.
  • Maximal cardiac output is increased as maximal heart rate and stroke volumes are increased.

Key Takeaway:

  • Cardiac output=Stroke volume * heart rate
  • Due to training heart rate is reduced below 60/min. But stroke volume is increased due to hypertrophy of cardiac muscles. No change in resting cardiac output occurs.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female visited the primary care physician for his weakness and easy fatigability. Doctor investigated her and found her MCV is 75 fl. The RBCs in this female is
questions.solution:
• MCV is the mean corpuscular volume of RBCs. It is the average volume of RBCs in blood.
  • MCV = Hct*10/ RBC (10⁶/microliter)
  • Hematocrit is the percentage of RBCs in total blood.
  • Normal MCV value is around 90 fl.
  • If it is < 80 fl RBCs are smaller known as microcytes. IF it is >95 fl RBCs are macrocytic.
  • Hypochromic RBCs are seen when hemoglobin is less in RBCs. It cannot be determined by MCV.
  • Microcytic RBCs are seen in
    • Iron deficiency anemia
    • Thalassemia
    • Anemia of chronic disease
    • Sideroblastic anemia

Key Takeaway:

  • Normal MCV value is aroud 90 fl.
  • If it is < 80 fl RBCs are smaller known as microcytes. IF it is >95 fl RBCs are macrocytic.
  • Hypochromic RBCs are seen when hemoglobin is less in RBCs. It cannot be determined by MCV.

choices.text: T4 binds to albumin more than T3
Most of T3 and T4 binds to thyroxine binding globulin
Transthyretin binds to thyroid hormone in maximum amount

questions.text: What is true about thyroid binding protein?
questions.solution:
• The plasma proteins that bind thyroid hormones are albumin, transthyretin (formerly called thyroxine-binding prealbumin), and thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG).
  • Albumin has the largest capacity to bind T4. TBG has the lowest capacity.
  • Most of the T4 binds to TBG due to its affinity.
  • Smaller amounts of T4 are bound to transthyretin and albumin.
  • The lesser binding of T3 correlates with the facts that T3 has a shorter half-life than T4 and that its action on the tissues is much more rapid.

Key Takeaway:

  • Albumin has the largest capacity to bind T4. TBG has the lowest capacity.
  • Most of the T4 binds to TBG due to its affinity.
  • Smaller amounts of T4 are bound to transthyretin and albumin.

questions.text: Which of the following factor does not increase the secretion of growth hormone?
questions.solution:
• All of the above factors increase the secretion of growth hormone from anterior pituitary gland.
  • During sleep large pulsatile secretion of growth hormone occurs. Especially during deep sleep. That is why it is said that " If you don't sleep you don't grow".
  • Growth hormone releasing hormone secreted from hypothalamus increases the secretion of growth hormone from anterior pituitary gland.
  • The main site of ghrelin synthesis and secretion is the stomach, but it is also produced in the hypothalamus and has marked growth hormone-stimulating activity.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: Sodium dependent phosphate transporters are present in the tubules of the kidney. Which of the following is powerfully inhibited by PTH hormone?
questions.solution:
• From the phosphate that reaches to the tubule nearly 90% is absorbed from the kidney.
  • This reabsorption mostly occurs via the active transport mechanism of sodium phosphate cotransporters.
  • There are 3 cotransporters for phosphate absorption regulation
    • NaPi-IIa
    • NaPi-IIb
    • NaPi-IIc
  • Parathyroid hormone reduces phosphate reabsorption from the tubules in the kidney.
  • NaPi-IIa is powerfully inhibited by PTH, which causes its internalization and degradation and thus a reduction in renal Pi reabsorption.
  • NaPi-IIb because of low intracellular Na+ conc. by Na, K ATPase on the basolateral membrane of intestinal epithelial cells moves phosphate against conc. gradient.
  • NaPi-IIc is present in the proximal tubules in the kidney to facilitate the phosphate reabsorption.

Key Takeaway:

  • NaPi-IIa is powerfully inhibited by PTH, which causes its internalization and degradation and thus a reduction in renal Pi reabsorption.
  • NaPi-IIb because of low intracellular Na+ conc. by Na, K ATPase on the basolateral membrane of intestinal epithelial cells moves phosphate against conc. gradient.
  • NaPi-IIc is present in the proximal tubules in the kidney to facilitate the phosphate reabsorption.

choices.text: GLUT 4 transporter induction on the cell membrane
Lowering on intracellular glucose level via glucokinase induction
5' AMP activated kinase in response to exercise

questions.text: Which of the following increases the entry of glucose into the cells?
questions.solution:
• The GLUT-4 transporters mediate glucose transport into the insulin sensitive cells. Activation of the insulin receptor causes activation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase, which speeds translocation of the GLUT-4-containing endosomes into the cell membrane.
  • In liver Insulin induces glucokinase, and this increases the phosphorylation of glucose, so that the intracellular free glucose concentration stays low, facilitating the entry of glucose into the cell.
  • A 5'-adenosine monophosphate (AMP)-activated kinase may trigger the insertion of GLUT4 vesicles into the cell membrane in response to exercise. This action is independent of insulin.

Key Takeaway:

Entry of glucose into cella is increased by :

  • GLUT 4 transporter induction on the cell membrane
  • Lowering on intracellular glucose level via glucokinase induction
  • 5' AMP activated kinase in response to exercise

questions.text: Cortisol binding globulin level is elevated in
questions.solution:
• Cortisol binding globulin also known as transcortin is bound to the majority of blood cortisol. Some Cortisol also binds to albumin.
  • The equilibrium between cortisol and its binding protein affects the free cortisol level which is important for cortisol effects.
  • CBG is synthesized in the liver and its production is increased by estrogen hormone.
  • When the CBG level rises, more cortisol is bound, and initially the free cortisol level drops. This stimulates ACTH secretion, and more cortisol is secreted until a new equilibrium is reached at which the bound cortisol is elevated. Free cortisol remains normal.
  • When CBG level falls opposite changes occur.
  • CBG levels are elevated during pregnancy
  • CBG level is depressed in cirrhosis, nephrosis and multiple myeloma.

KEY TAKE AWAY

  • CBG levels are elevated during pregnancy
  • CBG level is depressed in cirrhosis, nephrosis and multiple myeloma.

questions.text: Which of the following organs does not develop from the Mullerian duct in females?
questions.solution:
• The ovary develops from genital ridges if SRY gene is absent due to absence of Y chromosome. It develops from the medulla in the embryonic gonads.
  • Absence of MIS in females will grow Mullerian duct in females.
  • From Mullerian duct organs developed in females are
    • Fallopian tubes
    • Uterus
    • Cervix
    • Upper part of vagina
  • The external female genitalia develops from genital tubercle, urogenital fold and labioscrotal swellings.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Leptin is a hormone producing hunger
A girl with anorexia nervosa has decrease in level of leptin hormone
Leptin treatment can induce precocious puberty

questions.text: In following statements not true about leptin is
questions.solution:
• Critical body weight is very important to reach puberty in females.
  • Leptin is a hormone found in the fat cells in the body.
  • Strenuous athletes and girls with anorexia nervosa have very less fat stored in their body. Weight loss in these girls stops menstruation in a girl. In them, an increase in weight brings menstruation to normal.
  • Leptin deficiency can produce infertility.
  • Leptin treatment also induces precocious puberty in immature female.
  • The mechanism by which it occurs is still unknown.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: It is formed from corpus luteum
It is important for progesterone secretion

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Corpus albicans in a 28 days regular ovarian cycle?
questions.solution:
• After rupture of follicle at the time of ovulation the follicle is filled with blood is known as corpus hemorrhagicum.
  • After that the clotted blood is absorbed and it is replaced by yellowish lipid rich luteal cells. It is called corpus luteum.
  • If pregnancy occurs this corpus luteum persists and corpus albicans does not form. Corpus luteum secretes estrogen and progesterone in pregnancy.
  • If pregnancy does not occur, corpus luteum degenerates and degenerated corpus luteum is replaced by scar tissue about 4 days before menses.
  • This white tissue is known as corpus albicans.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: Glaucoma is caused by an increase in intraocular pressure. A 47-year-old female is suffering from blurring of vision due to primary glaucoma. Patient was given a drug that increases the outflow of aqueous humor. Which drug among the following can be given to increase the outflow?
questions.solution:
• Primary glaucoma: It occurs without any obvious systemic or ocular cause usually after the age of 40 yrs
    • Primary open angle glaucoma - due to sclerosis of trabecular meshwork
    • Primary angle closure glaucoma - due to closure of the angle of the anterior chamber.
  • The drugs helpful in glaucoma act via two mechanisms
    1. Via decreasing the secretion of aqueous humor
    2. Via increasing the outflow of aqueous humor
  • Drugs that increase in outflow of aqueous humor are cholinergic agonist drugs.
    • Pilocarpine, Physostigmine and carbachol are among them.
  • Drugs that decrease the secretion of aqueous humor are either
    • Adrenergic receptor antagonist (Timolol)
    • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (Dorzolamide, Acetazolamide)
    • Prostaglandins

KEY TAKE AWAY

choices.text: Endolymph has similar composition to ECF
K+ is continuously being secreted into the endolymph

questions.text: True about endolymphatic potential is
questions.solution:
• Following are the characteristics of the endolymphatic potential.
    • Endolymph has composition as that of intracellular fluid.
    • It has high K+ concentration & low Na+ concentration.
    • K+ is continuously being secreted into the endolymph by the vascular system.
    • High + charge in the endolymph.
    • There is around +80 mv potential difference between endolymph & perilymph.
    • This potential difference between endolymph and perilymph is k/a endolymphatic potential.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient visited the ER for chest pain and his BP was measured as SBP 190 mmHg, DBP 100 mmHg, Pulse pressure 90 mmHg. Which of the following parameter that should decrease for this high pulse pressure
questions.solution:
• Arterial wall compliance should decrease for the high pulse pressure.
  • The pulse pressure is the difference between the systolic and diastolic blood pressure.
  • With increment in age, there is increase in systolic blood pressure but there is decrease in diastolic blood pressure due to increased arterial stiffness which occurs due to decrease in arterial wall compliance which results in increase in pulse pressure.

questions.text: Decrease in central venous pressure leads to all the following except:
questions.solution:
Decrease in central venous pressure leads to decrease in atrial natriuretic factor.The rate of ANP secretion is proportional to the degree to which the atria are stretched by increases in central venous pressure.

Other options:

Decrease in central venous pressure leads to increase in angiotensin II, sympathetic activation and stimulates thirst.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy's parents took him to the pediatrician for routine checkup. Pediatrician evaluated him and found that he has a congenital defect in transport of neutral amino acids in the intestine. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hartnup disease is caused by a congenital defect in the mechanism that transports neutral amino acids in the intestine and renal tubules. It causes cystinuria.
  • Lactose intolerance occurs due to absence of lactase enzymes. It is a congenital defect. Due to inability to digest the lactose, it produces diarrhea, bloating and pain in the abdomen. Simplest treatment is to avoid dairy products.
  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten (a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye). It damages the small intestine lining by intestinal T cells, leading to malabsorption of nutrients.

Key Takeaway:
